title: 113_hr3357
content:
The "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" aims to assist States in enhancing the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators in various programs. This includes Head Start Programs, state-funded prekindergarten programs, licensed child care for prekindergarten children, and special education preschools. Grants are authorized for implementation by the Secretary of Education in collaboration with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Each State seeking a grant under the "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" must submit an application to the Secretary of Education with details of their early childhood professional development system, including collaboration with relevant organizations, designation of a grant program administrator, and an oversight structure. The summarized chunk includes the following key points:
- Oversight structure for the system
- Professional standards and competencies
- Career lattice
- Coordination with State higher education agencies and accrediting bodies
- Encouragement of articulation agreements between two- and four-year institutions
- More accessible higher education for working learners
- Support for adult learners from diverse backgrounds
- Use of workforce data to assess State's workforce needs The curr_chunk focuses on workforce needs and financing over time. The curr_chunk focuses on state use of funds. The State must use grant funds to provide scholarships for preschool teachers pursuing a bachelor's degree in early childhood education, support teachers with degrees in other fields to obtain credentials in early childhood education, increase compensation for teachers working towards a degree, and offer professional development opportunities. Opportunities for preschool teachers and teacher assistants in early childhood education programs focus on child development, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence for diverse children and families. Grant funds provided under this Act must supplement, not replace, other available Federal, State, and local funds for early childhood educator preparation and professional development. States receiving funds must maintain or increase their financial support for these activities each year. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019 to implement this Act.
